gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Depth soundings from a single beam echo sounder collected around the nearshore areas of Timor-Leste in 2012 and 2013

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Information about the NOAA Coral Reef Ecosystem Program's activities in the Coral Triangle.

Timor-Leste project portal on the NOAA Coral Reef Information Service website where NOAA's final report for Timor-Leste and the datasets generated by NOAA CREP as part of the project can be downloaded.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center. 2017. Interdisciplinary baseline ecosystem assessment surveys to inform ecosystem-based management planning in Timor-Leste: Final Report. Pacific Islands Fisheries Science Center, PIFSC Special Publication, SP-17-002, 234 p. https://doi.org/10.7289/V5/SP-PIFSC-17-002.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This dataset contains singlebeam bathymetry data acquired during small-boat surveys conducted from October 20-26, 2012 and June 4-27, 2013 in Timor-Leste by the NOAA Coral Reef Ecosystem Program (CREP). Data was acquired with a HydroLite-TM Echosounder Kit by Seafloor Systems, a small boat Hydro Survey System using Ohmex SonarMite echosounder and Trimble ProXT receiver. The singlebeam bathymetry was used to ground-truth bathymetry derived from WorldView-2 satellite imagery by CREP for the near-shore areas (0-20 m depths) around Timor-Leste.

gmd:purpose.gco:CharacterString:
In 2011, NOAA and the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) Timor-Leste Mission formed a 5-year bi-lateral partnership agreement from 2012 to 2016, in support of the Government of Timor-Leste—particularly the Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF)—by addressing significant information gaps in their nearshore marine ecosystems. Specifically, MAF asked NOAA to address the following questions:
1. Where are the nearshore marine resources?
2. What are the nearshore marine resources?
3. How are they changing over time and what threats are potentially causing these changes?
4. What approaches are needed to manage and conserve the nearshore marine resources?
With financial support from USAID and in-kind support from the NOAA Coral Reef Conservation Program (CRCP), the NOAA Coral Reef Ecosystem Program (NOAA-CREP) conducted baseline ecosystem assessment surveys to inform ecosystem-based management planning in Timor-Leste. The primary activities conducted by NOAA to answer these questions included:
1. satellite mapping of nearshore habitats,
2. conducting coral reef ecosystem assessments,
3. establishing ecological baselines for climate change, and
4. building management capacity by developing a spatial data framework
The singlebeam bathymetry data described herein resulted from the first activity to conduct satellite mapping for the nearshore waters around Timor-Leste.

gmd:credit.gco:CharacterString: PIFSC Coral Reef Ecosystem Program and funded by the United States Agency for International Development

gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: Assessing cryptic reef diversity of colonizing marine invertebrates using Autonomous Reef Monitoring Structures (ARMS) deployed at coral reef sites in Timor-Leste from 2012 to 2014

Calcification rates of crustose coralline algae (CCA) derived from Calcification Accretion Units (CAUs) deployed at coral reef sites in Timor-Leste from 2012 to 2014

Satellite-derived bathymetry for nearshore benthic habitats in Timor-Leste
Water chemistry at coral reef sites in Timor-Leste from discrete surface and bottom water samples collected in 2013 and 2014
Water temperature data from Subsurface Temperature Recorders (STRs) deployed at coral reef sites in Timor-Leste from 2012 to 2014
WorldView-2 Satellite Image Inventory for Timor-Leste

gmd:environmentDescription.gco:CharacterString:
Singlebeam bathymetry data collected using HydroLite-TM Sonarmite Echosounder Kit by Seafloor Systems, which includes:
1) SonarMite BT-TM system, portable bluetooth echo sounder 2) SonarMite Transducer w/mount 3) Trimble Pro6T GNSS Receiver 4) Recon/GPS controller 5) Survey pole w/transom mount
Echosounder specs: Frequency: 200 KHz Beam width: 4 degree Ping rate: 6-Hz Depth accuracy: 1 cm /0.1% of depth, Output: NMEA, ASCII, Quality Depth range: 0.3-75 m
Data from the 2012 surveys was processed in May 2013 by Julia Ehses using version 7 of the processing script. 2012 data log files saved on PIFSC network at \\PICMAKAI\General\Cruise\CruiseData\CTI_TIM_SBP1215\Trimble_Data_Logger_Downloads\
Data from the 2013 surveys was processed in December 2017 by Annette DesRochers using SonarVista - SonarMite Edit software (v6.12) from Seafloor Systems. 2013 source data files saved on PIFSC network at \\PICMAKAI\General\Cruise\CruiseData\CTI_TIM_SBP1310\Mapping\Hydrolite_Ecosounder\data_output\Timor_Leste\

gmd:supplementalInformation.gco:CharacterString:
Mission ID, 2012: SBP1215 Mission ID, 2013: SBP1310
Surveys were conducted from local Timorese boat charters: 2012/2013: Lancet, 27’ Boston Whaler for shore-based surveys 2012: Cattitude, 40’ live-aboard catamaran 2013: Sundancer NT, 50’ live-aboard catamaran

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: Depth soundings collected during small-boat surveys around the nearshore areas of Timor-leste by the NOAA Coral Reef Ecosystem Program in Oct 2012 and June 2013. Archived with the NCEI Trackline Geophysical Data portal (search by survey/mission id SBP1215 or SBP1310).

gmd:evaluationMethodDescription.gco:CharacterString:
Depth: The HydroLite-TM Echosounder Kit, Sonarmite Echosounder has a depth accuracy of 1 cm / 0.1% of depth.
2012: The fix type, number of satellites, and HDOP are provided in the dataset. HDOP is a measure of the geometric quality of a GPS satellite configuration in the sky. HDOP is a factor in determining the relative accuracy of a horizontal position. The smaller the DOP number, the better the geometry.
2013: The type and QA is provided in the dataset. Records with a type = L indicate the depth record includes the GPS location and has a QA = 1 (NMEA tag for GPS fix). There are two 'type = D' records for every 'type = L' record (D=Depth), because the sonar pings every half second, which is more frequent than the GPS. For the 'type=D' records, the higher the QA, the better the return signal strength. QA=70 is low signal strength (not as good), QA = 130 is high return signal strength (better).
The HydroLite-TM Echosounder Kit, Sonarmite Echosounder has a depth range of 0.3 m – 75 m.
Obviously erroneous data based on the coordinates were cleaned from the dataset (coordinates outside the expected range for Timor-Leste; 0,0 pairs, etc).
As the survey was not conducted to meet IHO standards, all users should independently analyze the dataset according to their own needs and standards to determine data usability.

gmd:statement.gco:CharacterString: Singlebeam bathymetry data collected using HydroLite-TM Echosounder Kit by Seafloor Systems, a small boat Hydro Survey System using Ohmex SonarMite echo sounder and Trimble ProXT receiver. Data was collected following procedures established by Seafloor Systems, and the HydroLite-TM system was tested and calibrated in advance of the surveys. Soundings were recorded in meters. Data collected in 2012 were processed using a different method from that used in 2013 as described in the process steps.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: GPS track data (NMEA) and depths were downloaded and processed/parsed in ArcGIS using a customized track processing script written in Python. A time offset was applied to capture local time in Timor-Leste in addition to Greenwich Mean Time (GMT). The processed/parsed data were exported to an Esri geodatabase and erroneous data were cleaned in ArcGIS. The cleaned data were exported to CSV to be archived.

During 2013 surveys, the system was calibrated for sound velocity. A log was kept during the surveys, including the offset from the instrument to the water surface (20 or 30 cm, depending on the vessel) and the sound velocity calibration status. The SonarMite data (.SOM) was downloaded from the instrument and imported into SonarVista, offsets and calibration were applied, obviously erroneous data based on the coordinates were removed, and the processed data were exported to CSV format. The exported data are considered 'lightly processed' and should be further inspected and cleaned before use.

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Access Constraints: None | Use Constraints: None
